hints_html: Remember that the rate of change of a quantity \(z\) is just the derivative of that quantity with respect to time, (i.e: dz/dt).
hints_latex:
Remember that the rate of change of a quantity $z$ is just the
derivative of that quantity with respect to time, (i.e: dz/dt).
hints_raw: Remember that the rate of change of a quantity <math>z</math> is just the derivative of that quantity with respect to time, (i.e: dz/dt).
question: 7 (i)
sols_html:
The question is asking us to find the rate of change of the variable x. (i.e: We want to solve for dx/dt). Using implicit differentiation and the equation \(y = x^{2}\) we will derive a value for these quantities as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dt}y &= \frac{d}{dt}x^{2} \\ \frac{dy}{dt} &= 2x\frac{dx}{dt} \quad \rightarrow \quad \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{2x}\frac{dy}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

From the information about the rate of change of y at the point P, we make the appropriate substitutions in the equation to determine dx/dt:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{2(2)}8 = 2 \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\frac{dx}{dt} =2}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve \(y = x^{2}\). As it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

i) Find \(dx/dt\) at the instant the particle is at the point P.
statement_latex:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve $y = x^{2}$. As
it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its \emph{y} coordinate changes
at a rate of 8 units/sec.

i) Find $dx/dt$ at the instant the particle is at the point P.
statement_raw:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve <math>y = x^{2}</math>. As it passes through
the point P = (2, 4), its ''y'' coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

i) Find <math>dx/dt</math> at the instant the particle is at the point P.
